page.title: 13HORTON KIRBY PAPER MILLS
page.content: Built in 1820 this mill was origin- ally a flour mill. After being con- verted to paper making, a workforce of approximately 100 locals was employed. The paper made was good quality, used for glossy magazines and Dyeline base paper for copying plans. The mill, then and still, uses pure water from an Artesian well. Two chimneys were used originally, the smaller being demolished 20 years ago as it was no longer required. The larger was built in 1881 and had 35 ft. added by a German firm in 1914. This amount was removed for safety reasons in the 1970's. An overheated glazing cylinder exploded in the early 1980's, leading to the rebuilding of the workshop. The paper mill now only produces woodchip wallpaper, employing approx. 40 workers. 20 small firms rent units from the mill and more are expected.
